# Mountains

It's a giant mountain range with many parts and a long history.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/o4WPVsOKQsi2LkpzKc5z)

# Valley

Within the mountain are many valleys where the Fernborn have settled. Lots of space for fog to settle.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/FTzNueZRAqdfVdWuAnb3)

# Fog The microclimate of the Valley results in seasonal fog. From spring to autumn, the valley is covered in various levels of fog. Only in the winter does the fog clear, granting full display of the short days and shallow light.

# Peaks

The peak visible from around the Valley are important for orientation and are considered sacred by many.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/4TMG63NeRASMRDCLXMnN)

# Caves The Valley has many cave systems. Some were settled, but those have since been sealed due to "dangers." The caves are said to hold nightmares and bad luck. Few Valley residents question the decision or desire exploring, happily keeping above ground.
# Mountain fauna

# Monsters

There legends of monsters looming in the fog. Their stories were used to keep kids away from the woods but maybe some of the tales hold truth (i.e. symbionts). Tales often contain details of glowing eyes, moans and whispers, silhouettes.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/RyD6fp3aToqPX5u9lAst)

# Salamanders

In the wet mountains, many salamanders live in seasonal pools and stream beds. Their migration patterns sometimes symbolize the pilgrimage of the Fernborn. Some salamanders are quite poisonous and have been long used for healing and harm.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/CGdWk7vvRnOcTuVfirz2)

# Snails

There are a bunch of snails; they co-evolved with the moist environment.

Snail shells are collected and used for games and made into jewelry. Maybe there's something interesting about the chirality of the snail shell.

Many plants have strong smells to attract pollinators who have limited visual signals in the fog. The Valley is well know particularly for its orchids.

Along with ferns, the fog provides a perfect environment for moss and lichen.

The mountains are rich in minerals. The Fernborn have created much wealth for themselves crafting and trading the minerals extracted from the mountain. They produce some of the rarest metals and gems in the world along with the techniques required to use and shape them.

# Lyric's Rivers
# River features

# Basin A large drainage basic empties out at a single point into the ocean, creating a massive river delta. Over time, the main river has shifted several times, creating a unique, moving landscape. Its main rivers are well-travelled but human and animal alike.

# Coast

The edges and coast of the river delta slowly ebb and flow with every season. It is mostly filled with animals and wet, sedimentary deposits. Movement across this region is slower but the Riverspun have developed techniques to flow through it.

# Wetlands The many changes to the river delta's flow has resulted in wetlands of varying properties. Some are fresh, some are brackish, some are drier, some are wetter, some have trees, others have seasonal plants.

# Delta

The ancient homeland of the Riverspun people is an large river delta. The delta's tributaries (its accumulated river sources) and distributaries (its breaking up into branches) are well mapped and act as established trade routes.

# River fauna

Many aquatic and semi-aquatic species have migratory patterns that include the delta and its basin in their route: salamanders, turtles, fish, frogs, you name it. The plants of the rivers have their insect companions that provide food for larger terrestrial and aquatic predators. Do you like bats? They've got them! Otters and other small aquatic mammals too. Plus other water drinkers like deer and wild cats.

# River flora

All the plants in the river delta love water and move along with it. The trees are highly adapted to sitting in water. Grasses and sedges love water and sand; water lilies love water so much its in their name; carnivorous plants that like water bugs are in for a treat.

# Seasons

Seasons have a great effect on the river delta and its water ways. Every summer, when the snow in the mountains starts to melt, rivers run rapid and may overflow in areas. Seasonal drought may prevent movement by boat. Seasons also result in migratory behavior of many animals along the rivers and coast.

Originated as warmth for foggy temperature drops. Easy to take on and off. Also creates triangular form in body. Over time, capes got wrapped up into status symbols and the elite have really fancy ones.

Triangular. Mirror the mountain peaks. Mostly used in formal settings: religious practice, educational system, government work.

# Fernborn organization

# Estates For as long as the Fernborn have sought escape from the fog, family clans have build grand estates along the valley‚Äôs mountainsides. Although many began with terraced agriculture, modern industry has shifted to artisanal craft and trade. Many also serve as private universities. They have amassed great wealth over generations and build their estates with exquisite mansions often adorned with greenhouses and gardens. Many are sites along pilgrimage routes with shrines of common ancestral figures.

# Universities

In their quest for technological progress and luxury artisanal craft, estates began inviting and housing master crafts people, scholars, and teachers. Neighboring estates would share these resources and a formal university system was developed in the Valley.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/Rh4sxfqSRy9PKAEwvli2)

# Hamlets

In the foggy mountain valleys, hamlets utilizing dry stone sheltered their inhabitants. Modern technology has upgraded the houses of the lowland valley, but old structures aren't uncommon. Many are repurposed into storage or workshop

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/XimwAdE4QyGA6iD8cqG3)
# Fernborn craft

# Perfumery

Like many trades, the Fernborn have mastered the art of perfumery. Perfumes are quite fashionable as modern society attempts cover up natural body scent, often associated with lower-class labor.

Modern perfumery builds upon an older tradition of incense which is stilled used in certain religious ceremonies, shrines, and cemeteries. 

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/ORQPcrB9QaedD4Cb592z)

# Mosaics

Mosaics and other tiled stonework predate modern trends utilizing glass. Commonly used in bath houses, shrines, entryways, and arts venues. Very period.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/7fI4dk1YTHuxmXlaFucD)

# Lamps

Light has always been sacred to the Fernbon. In a mountain valley often covered in fog, light is not always plentiful. The sun is a gift that is never taken for granted.

As proxies for light, lamps have always been important for the hard-workers in the mountain valley. Open flame become contained. Fuel-burning lanterns became electric. Indeed, modern cities have street lamps illuminated late into the night to allow for longer work days and longer play days.

Modern style utilizes delicate glasswork and glass colored by minerals mined from the mountain. The lamps of the Fernborn are coveted around the world.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/j0Hl4IQiRf6gWaKMbJQv)

# Statues

Great stone statues are carved throughout the Valley representing the more ancient and powerful Fernborn. The oldest clans dispute claim over certain ancestral figures. Some statues are remote and comprise a network of pilgrimage sites. Some great statues have been forgotten and abandoned, overgrown in the surrounding forests.

Over time, these larger statues become smaller faces carved in homes and public areas (like grotesques). In cities, ancestral carving has led to a culture of mosaics and stained glass glamorizing more modern heroes and celebrities.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/AKLNUrtpQy6rBXN2qZvQ)

# Stonework

In a mountain range rich in stone, the Fernborn have mastered many stoneworking techniques in art and architecture.

It‚Äôs carved into great ancestral monuments and led to a writing system that originated in stone-carving.

Among artisans, stones are praised for their unique qualities, including impurities and origins.

Modern trends move away from stone into more refined materials such as glass and metal.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/kqqCL9TRTsOcr8NBEmf0)
# Fernborn architecture

# Stained glass

The Fernborn's love and mastery of glass is nowhere as apparent as in their windows and stained glass. Most stained glass is used in elegant window designs, but recent innovations lean toward the figurative, including family trees and modern celebrities.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/aOTLfCe5TTyzb21Y8mV8)

# Towers

Originally, towers symbolized escape from the fog and reaching toward the sun. In the old days, they were used for yodeling and other far communication to cut through the fog.

Modern cities still use towers but their use has changed. Now, they are in police surveillance, in escaping surveillance to discuss secret things, and to boast status.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/2yiocff2QL6ahtHY8fRI)

Modern city architecture is dominated by pointy roofs and domes.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/OIC2XvDaSYq9vFZRai4h)

# Greenhouses

Glass is a common resource for the Fernborn and they've used their mastery of it to create elegant greenhouses. Most greenhouses belong to estates to keep climate-controlled plants, often imported from warmer regions.

They also produce many of the rare plants used in perfumery and cuisine.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/apXJPYiRjutdqU57hCVw)

# Slopes

Settling on the often steep mountainsides of a valley requires ingenuity. The Fernborn use the natural shape of the mountains to their advantage in technology. Terraced farming is pervasive, cave and cliff dwellings are common, and larger cities grow up mountainsides. The upper class use their clearance of fog and proximity to sun as markers of status and entitlement.

# Fernborn belief

# Cemeteries

For the ancestor-worshiping Fernborn, cemeteries have a long tradition. Their visitation and maintenance were once central parts of spirituality life and family history, but modern times have seen a decline in this practice. Smaller shrines and alters symbolize the abstract ancestor.

Traditional cemeteries use lamps which are said to provide shelter for the soul of the deceased. Keeping the stone lamp clean is important, and bringing and offering of flame/light is the proper honoring.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/EMm4SlkgRD6oBgAGKvlh)

# Sun

There are many theories as to the honoring of light and the sun in Ferborn culture.

One theory suggests that foggy conditions made the light precious. The sun was celebrated during clear skies and architecture attempted to maximize available light, such as an orientation to the low-angled winter sun (the Valley's clearest season).

Another theory states that the sun is the original ancestor from which all life derived.

Widespread utilization of lamps and windows are seen as modern effects of more primitive sun worship.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/kxgWxaiVTrWmFiq5EPPy)

# Ancestry

The Fernborn are an ancient people. Lineage, bloodlines, and ancestry play a central role in the lives and organization of Fernborn citizens.

The ancient fern that fills the mountain valley has been adopted as the symbol for old family lines. It is where their name, the Fernborn, arose.

Ancestor worship is central to the spiritual culture of Fernborn. Large stone monuments are carved in the likeness of ancestral heroes. Over time, these monuments have been replaced by a culture of statue and celebrity.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/uPj2ML2TmyD6OEmOQMlj)
# Fernborn themes

# Triangles

Triangles are a common motif among the Fernborn. They represent the mountain and are a metaphor for many hierarchical aspects of society. Triangles are often seen in art, architecture, and apparel.

![](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/P9rd1QvMRiCXvRx4By46)

# Riverspun


The Riverspun are a largely nomadic society whose homeland is in the river delta of a large drainage basin. They have mastered the waters and developed a culture of trade, hard work, and craftsmanship. They have many old customs and traditions to preserve their distributed culture, including the use of masks and tattoos, rejection of modern technology, and storytelling.
# Riverspun appearance

# Tattoos Public tattoos are applied to the chin and the hands and feet to communicate work, legacy, and nature. Private tattoos are applied elsewhere to convey experiences and beliefs. Tattoos mimic the flowing nature of the river. While trading and during ceremony, the Riverspun wear masks. While masked, they use their public tattoos to identify each other.

# Trimmed or tatted

Robe trim and tattoos use the same (similar) symbol sets.

**Trim**
  - embroidered
  - removable
  - colored
  - public
  - signaling

**Tattoo**
  - "cursive"
  - permanent
  - limited palette
  - private
  - remembering

If trim is public and tattoos are intimate, your hidden parts (trials?) are what you try to hide from others (or yourself).

# Braids Using their intimate knowledge of fibers, the Riverspun often grow their long and braid it into intricate designs. Despite the heavily gendered society, hairstyles do not differ consistently between genders.
# Robes The Riverspun flaunt their mastery of cloth in their robes. Robes have a long and important cultural role. They especially aid in signaling and in conformity/anonymity.

# Robe periods

**Birth robe**. Growing so much during your younger years, it's used as a wrap. After your first growth spurt (~3) when it's easier to predict your size and shape), it's turned into a childhood cloak. Used throughout adolescence, parents maintain it.

**Fool's robe**. As you start puberty (~10), you get the robe you'll grow into for early adulthood. This is also when you join your first work family, and the material used is often provided by them

**World robe**. After a major achievement in adulthood (most commonly reaching a certain status in a profession), you "graduate" from your childhood. This robe is a sign of high status and is better fit and adapted to personal style.

May have seasonal variations if you have the space or the need.

# Under cloak, vest over

- Under cloak: *layered, complex, loose, flowing*
- Vest over: *flat, straight, blocking, structured*

# Adaptive layering

Living on the water, the **weather changes** frequently. They need a style that can **adapt to exposure** (sun, heat, rain, cold).

Per season, have three primary cloaks: for **work**, for **worship**, and for **winding** down. Vests **complement** the robes and are interchanged more regularly.

# Judgment and maintenance

Since cloaks are kept so long, they must be **maintained** or they soon fall into disrepair. They are made from a **durable** material that takes a while to "cure." It starts out **coarse and rigid** but **softens over time**.

There's a lot of **judgment** (and signaling) from the **ware and cleanliness** of your robe. Well-worn robes are seen as a sign of **hard work**. Cleanliness and quality of upkeep is seen as a signal of **character**.

# Robe reuse

Each robe is **reincorporated** into the next. Shows history. i.e. Family cloth shows parental **lineage**, working cloth shows early **profession**.

The robes of the deceased are used in **mementos**. Sometimes the robes of the living are gifted to signal favor or **association**.

# Trim tales

The trim of the robe is the most important part. It starts empty and is slowly embroidered over a person's life. 

- Major life events
- Recognition
- Alliance
- Membership
- Identity
- Skills and ability

Unlike tattoos, embroidering can be undone as life changes.

Don't want too many different kinds of symbols or ones that compete‚Äîit becomes harder to others to quickly read.

# Formal pleats

Formal culture uses a lot of **pleats**. They are carefully **folded** and require care and maintenance to properly upkeep.

Inspiration: saris, hakama

# Tails tied up

Trailing fabric is tied up in several ways to **protect** the cloth or to increase **mobility** during certain activities. Tying is an integral part of outfitting oversized robes in young people. **Harnesses** are commonly used to aid in secure attachment and support.

# Misfits

Misfits in society can be literally interpreted. People who don't grow into their robes or outgrow them are often teased or looked down upon.

- Trans folks
- Overweight people
- Stunted growth

# Modernization of tradition

Modern nomadic culture loosens much of traditional dress culture. They are generally more **casual** and **borrow style** and material from the places they visit.

Traditions and formality are often maintained in the Delta. Relaxation of formal tradition is seen as an erosion of culture.
# Riverspun organization

# Guilds

  Many tribes make up the Riverspun across every family profession. They are older and usually tied to blood. Some tribes specialize in niche professions, but most tribes have a range of families that make them up. During congregations in the delta, tribe members across family come together.

# Trade outposts

Along vital routes, strategic outposts incorporate themselves into existing coastal towns and cities. They **adapt local styles** into permanent stilt structures or build **docks** that anchor houseboats longterm.

# Nomadic sailors

Nomadic guilds travel in pods of **houseboats** along seas and waterways in seasonal migrations. Guilds **specialize** their houseboats to the nature of their work. Boats fly numerous **flags** to signal their services. Many houseboats grow **rooftop gardens** and detachable **wagons** to facilitate trade.

*Barn quilts.*

# Homeland nests

In more recent times, stationary outposts have rooted in the delta region. The swamps and marshes of the area  **stilted houses**. Larger settlements occur on more solid ground and incorporate **imported materials** and techniques into traditional styles.

Across their clothing and handiwork interweave distinct ribbons that create intricately beautiful loops and knots.

# Riverspun architecture

# Boats Highly specialized boats serve homes, workshops, shops, and transport for the Riverspun. Boats and their professional families are marked with flags. Depending on the work of the family, the boat may be a single ferry, a house boat attached to a gallery boat, a small fleet of canoes. Aesthetic styles of boat vary by tribe.

# Dams

Damming affects portions of the river delta basin, both created by human and animal. The reservoirs they produce have become an important part of the ecosystem.

# Stilts The river is an ever-changing torrent. The Riverspun have adapted their more permanent architecture to account for the flooding of the rivers and coming and going of tides by building their houses on many strong but flexible stilts.
# Riverspun technology

# Cartography

When you travel as much as the Riverspun do, you learn to navigate and map things out pretty quickly. The Riverspun use all the tools available to them: the position of the moon, sun, and stars; landmarks in the local landscape; curves of the river and the paths they make. Although most Riverspun live on the river, many chart out landmasses during their rooted apprenticeships.

# Language

Although the Riverspun are known for their many stories and technical craftwork, they lack their own written language, preferring oral tradition with supplementary materials (knots and tapestry, usually). Recently, many have started adopting shared trade languages that have quickly bled into the older spoken language.

# Trade

The Riverspun see themselves as pollinators and curators of culture. They specialize at early ages and join work families to master trades but learning from and trading for rare and useful tools. Although this could bring them great wealth, they reject money and live simple lives with their modest belongings.

![A clever knot used to secure a bucket to a hook with thick rope, detailed via progressive diagrams](https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/vT006xYrRMyuUJG1kCms)

They have adopted a culture of apprenticeship where young citizens spend periods of time on land, working for craftspeople and learning their skills. As a result, they produce fine crafts and many excel in the arts.

# Riverspun beliefs

# Superstition The Riverspun are a very traditional people, including in their superstitions. They reject modern technology and magic, yet they incorporate charms, remedies, and divination into their daily lives. Rather than seeing their beliefs as magical, they see themselves as using mystical instruments to observe the world as it is.

# Signaling as ego reinforcement

The Riverspun are very concerned with the images they project. Their robes are used for many social functions.

This perhaps leads to compartmentalization of the personality (public, private, secret), hypercontrol of image, obsession over identity and signaling.
# Riverspun themes

# Cycles

The moon and the seasons are central to the Riverspun. The moon follows a short cycle from new to full to new again. The seasons follow a longer one, either moving toward light or toward darkness. They understand the rhythms of plants and animals that move in sync with the world's cycles.

Sun as god, night is when god blinks, new moon is when the inner eye blinks. (Sun as the eternal eye, the full moon still sees the sun / is seen by it through a mirror.)

# Shakshuka

**Principles**

- This dish is supposed to taste stewy
  - Cook things slowly, for a long time
    - High temperatures will caramelize the outsides and leave the insides less cooked
    - Lower temperatures for a long time will result in more natural sweetness and flavor balance
    - To do this, cook in a cast iron pan under low heat
      - Cast iron better distributes heat than other metals
        - The type/thickness of metal evens itself out smoothly
    - It helps to cover the pan at various points
      - Covering prevents moisture loss and conserves heat
      - It contains the steam which makes sure the tops are cooked too
- Taste as you go
  - Experience the transformation of the dish
- You can make in large quantities without much extra effort

**History**

**Prepare**

- Bring the pan to temperature first with plenty of olive oil
  - Oil adds flavor and helps the first ingredients begin their cooking process
- Cut up your stuff early
  - This makes sure you don't try to multitask, e.g. letting your oil get too hot while you're chopping or forget an ingredient in your rush
- Chill out
- This dish takes a while but doesn't require your full attention
  - You'll smell things
  - You gotta remember to stir it occasionally, so don't do something too involved or removed from the pan
- Since it's so slow, you can clean as you go

**Cook the foundation**

- Start with onions and peppers
  - Onion is an important flavor enhancer (it's in a family called aromatics)
  - Peppers add sweetness and their own flavor that complements the tomato
  - Cook first so they get soft
    - The acidity of the tomatoes slows down the cooking of other vegetables
    - The high water content of tomatoes also affects cooking time
  - You could add the garlic and spices here or later
- Add tomatoes after onions + peppers are cooked enough
  - You can add a bit of water if you want to leave it cooking for longer and do something like work on your video game
- The longer it cooks, the deeper and more complex the flavors
- As it reduces, make sure it has enough water so it doesn't burn on the pan

**Spices the dish**

- Strong spices give a lot of character to the base dish, they add flavor, aroma, and personality
  - Certain flavors and blends also give cultural flavor profiles
- Not required, so you can omit them for a more neutral dish or one that you want to use for multiple purpose
- I'm putting in garlic with the spices, but a lot of people add them with the aromatics (like onion) 
- There are lots of spices you can use
  - Cumin, paprika, and cayenne are traditional
  - Coriander and caraway also common
  - You could use red pepper or gochugaru (Korean ground chili)
- For spices, you can toast them whole or ground
  - Grinding them before or after allows them to blend in with the stew
    - Ground spices lose their flavor more quickly, especially when stored long term
    - If they're ground before toasting, they'll burn quicker
    - You probably won't grind them if cooking them with other ingredients
  - Leaving them whole look nice, add subtle texture, and give small bursts of flavor
- You can toast spices in the oven (not sure about the garlic)
- You can cook with oil in a pan
  - You can do this after the first round of onion/pepper
    - Make a well in the middle and heat them there
  - You can do this after reducing the tomatoes
    - Same concept but there's more water to interfere
  - You could do this at the beginning, but they'll maybe burn
    - The onions and peppers don't have a lot of moisture immediately so they might not cool down enough and continue to cook
  - You can cook it in a separate pan for more control
  - You can add liquid to immediately lower the temperature (like tomatoes)
  - Don't leave the stove, it'll be quick, like a minute
  - You can add the spices to cold oil so that they heat up more slowly
- Spices are done when they become very fragrant and start to brown
  - They're really easy to burn, be careful!


**Embellishments and adjustments**

- Do last taste tests and adjustments
- After you add the eggs, it'll be harder to mix around and distribute
- The dish should be pretty balanced: acidity from the tomatoes, sweetness from the slow-cooked pepper and onion, a savory quality from the slow-cooked tomatoes
- Adjust salt, knowing that it might not need a lot more since it's already so savory
  - You could even under salt it, knowing you'll add a finishing salt while serving
- Adjust spices or spiciness
  - Black pepper is familiar, cayenne is traditional, you could use chili flakes
  - Tunisia adds harissa
  - Don't worry about toasting them if you're already at the end
- You could add meats
  - Maybe you serve it with a sausage at the end
  - Maybe you grind up the meat, like sausage, chorizo, or lamb
  - Consider what kind of texture they'll contribute
- You could add potatoes and/or beans for more heft and a creamy firm texture

**Serve**

- Poach the eggs
  - There's a lot of water content so it evens the heat and prevents the eggs from cooking to quickly or coagulating (getting bright yellow and getting hard instead of being thick and smooth)
  - The faster you poach, the more chance you'll over or undercook the eggs
  - If you do it slow and steady, the yolk gets very gooey
  - Set a timer for these, you really don't want to forget, and they won't have any smell clues
    - Eggs cook pretty predictable, figure out your ideal egg time (for me it's like 5 or 6m)
    - Lean toward undercooking them than overcooking them (depending on personal preference, ofc)
  - Cover: steaming cooks the yolks from all directions
  - Do this at the end so they don't sit around and continue to cook or cool
- If it needs more salt, a large-grain salt will contribute crunchiness
- Could add some fresh herbs for garnish
  - They add color and bursts of fresh flavor
  - Parsley is nice
    - Softer herb: not too strong but distinct
    - Bright green color contrasts the red/orange of the stew and white/yellow of the eggs
  - If you've got an herb garden, use something fresh!
- Could add some creaminess
  - Soft cheese (like feta or salty sheep's milk) adds creaminess and saltiness
  - Yogurt adds tartness and creaminess
- Could serve with bread: pita, baguette, sourdough fried in olive oil
  - If you don't want or have a fork, bread can be used as a utensil
- Could accompany with mint tea
- Could serve alongside pickled vegetables
  - Add a sour element, crispy freshness, fiber and nutrients
  - Can be preserved at their peak and used later when tomatoes are in season
- Could serve alongside preserved lemon for a complex sweetness/sourness
- Could add olives or artichoke hearts or sardines or whatever

# Windtamed overview

The Windtamed are the indigenous people of a recently colonized archipelago. Historically, a shield of high wind and sharp rocks protected the archipelago its surrounding waters. After the wind's ominous disappearance, the mainland empire arrived with religious missionaries and colonists. Over time, the islands were modernized and deforested, sharing their newly acquired agriculture and timber with their landlocked neighbors.

# Archipelago The archipelago inhabited by the Windtamed is a set of islands located in a bay (formerly) protected by high winds and sharp rocks. It is home to many endangered species of moths and butterflies, birds, and salt-tolerant plants.
# Coves The islands are home to a number of hidden coves which contain unique plants and creatures and are often used for temporary refuge and smuggling in modern days.

# Empire According to published history, after the wind's abandonment, a religious empire sent aid to the archipelago and help them modernize and walk the stable path of God rather than follow the fickle and selfish spirits. Could it have been them that killed the wind to open up the bay for trade? Of course not! Did they spread campaigns to replace the fertile forests of the islands with farms to feed the empire? Ludicrous!
# Moths The archipelago have a large number of endemic species, as islands often have. Here, moths make up a large number of these species, unable to cross the large bodies of water.

# Families

Family has always been important for the Windtamed. Although the soil of the archipelago is fertile, the Windtamed kept their agriculture small, working alongside the entities of nature instead of overpowering them. Between food farmed and foraged, resources were scant but not scarce. Population numbers remained steady and families consisted of three adults and three children with many shared responsibilities. When the empire arrived, they preached that homosexuality was apart from God's Path: the ideal family was a wife, husband, and many kids to work the fields and find others to walk along the Path. Now, large families are encouraged to produce labor for the growing farms.
# Farming Massive clearcutting of the island was done to produce rich farmland with high yields. Who was all the food for? Certainly not the residents of the island, their faith promotes asceticism.

# Fauna The archipelago is known for its migratory animals, especially turtles and crabs, moths and butterflies, and birds. Like many island groups, the physical separation of species has resulted in highly diverse and specialized species. In addition to birds and insects, the island is also home to a number of small mammals.

# Flora

The native plants of the islands are tolerant of high winds and little fresh water. Around the shores are salt-tolerant plants including a large number of colorful succulents. Old growth forests contain a species of giant tree that can withstand the high winds they evolved in: their wood is strong yet flexible. Many specialized fungus species also exist, enabling the trees and understory plants to communicate.

# Forests The forests that remain are a cultural taboo. In recent years, deforestation has slowed and the remaining forests are protected, their inhabitants left alone. It is said that all the spirits and the queers fled to the forests where they still reside, attempting to keep out of sight when they interact with the world outside the forests. Over the years, some villages and sects of the church began growing along their borders, allowing interaction with the forest dwellers. Even so, it is widely believed that they are surrounded by the spirits of the forest, their curse infectious to those they spend time around. The architecture of many forest homes uses the living plants shaped over time. Even so, these forests are filled with ruins of old villages.

# Lighthouses With the disappearance of the wind, foreign boats could sail through the waters if they were familiar with the rocky bay. A number of lighthouses positioned on the islands double as sources of light for travellers caught in the dark and as religious temples for the island citizens.

# Ocean

Beyond the bay containing the archipelago, the vast ocean has inspired much lore of the Windtamed. The high winds and frequent storms dissuaded them from exploring the vast ocean, as their boats were more suited for short travel between islands and to the mainland. Without wind, the empire has developed new ships that open a high-traffic trade route buffered by the islands.

# Paper

Since high winds would blow it away, paper was historically reserved for things specifically intended to fly. Now, paper used mostly for things that can't fly (since there's no wind): bookmaking, origami, and fine art.

# Port God teaches us that from every tragedy is born a new hope for the future. Although the winds blew away and never returned, it enabled the steady ocean to carry new ideas and wonders through the bay. Without the organizational efforts of the mainlanders, the islands would have never succeeded as lighthouse-filled ports on their own. What a waste that would have been.

# Race Living under the shade of their forests, the Windtamed are light skinned with almond eyes and peach-stained cheeks (like in Siberia). After the arrival of the empire and the upheaval of the primitive family structure (God is the third parent, not some gay person), marriage became a way for natives to ensure wealth for their family and status within the church.

# Religion

The religion spread by the mainlanders preaches that the wind abandoned the islanders and their way of life. The god of the empire guided them to sail to the archipelago and aid their endangered inhabitants. The Windtamed were taught by missionaries that the spirits of nature that they worshipped were dangerous and selfish. Their God played no tricks; He is loving and cares for all who walk alongside Him. With the forests cleared and the wind vanished, few encountered spirits of nature. The ones that did venture near humans were often angry and struggling to survive, making them easy targets for the church to decry.

# Style The old art style made use of solid color blocks with heavy lines and much metaphorical imagery. The empire introduced the islands to painting and realism and today, the styles have mixed. They wear many hats to keep their fair skin out of the sun. They are also know for their bright colors, once from the their extensive knowledge of forest plants, now imported. Winters are more harsh without the forest protection, so clothing utilizes fur and wool.

The language of the Windtamed is syllabary with an emphasis on composition into increasingly complex/abstract terms and their corresponding symbols. Writing was originally carved into wood and based on the hexagon. Since the arrival of the mainlanders, a variant of the imperial alphabet is used to write out the syllables onto paper with ink pens.

The Windtamed get their name from a long history influenced by the high winds surrounding the archipelago. The wind granted the archipelago protection: no one but the Windtamed could navigate the sharp rocks to travel in or out of the bay the islands inhabit. The winds were rejoiced. # Why a game?

* It's what I know, what I have passion for
* Game industry is really limited right now, there's a ton of opportunity to enrich and explore the medium
  * "Traditional gamers" need help, don't have a lot of good teachers or role models in games
* Don't want to "teach" people, want to give opportunities for play
  * Game topics not intended to replace their physical counterparts; aimed to be an intro/inspo to spark interest to explore in the world
* Want to incorporate a story into the larger topics I'm exploring

# "Educational game"

I do see the game having "educational" elements (like learning how to read the night sky or learning about animal behavior) but I don't want it to feel like a traditional educational game. I think folks are generally good at seeing through appearances and don't like being "taught at."

Ideally, I'd like to build the engine and tools so that folks could use the systems already encoded to build more straightforward "educational experiences" if the wanted.

# Feeling of adventure

Feeling of *Zelda: Link to the Past*
* adventurous
* self contained
* evocative
* otherwordly
* heroic

Imagining a more inclusive vision of the Hero's Journey, we could see the type of adventure exemplified by Zelda just one portion of a larger journey

Healer's Journey?

Imagine *Part One* having three Zelda-like games. Each is small and cozy, focused on the adventure of individual characters.

Interact with a shared world, sometimes with overlap. Feel separate and self-driven but move within a larger current.

Each character with their own heroic arc. Adventure is only a part of the journey; others parts center around healing, resolution, doldrums.

Full arc of a character may span many games, but each game is self-contained. *Part One* might have the adventure of one and the maturity of another.

# Unsolvable problems

Important problems are complex problems, and complex problems require complex solutions‚Äîif they have solutions at all. While I want Part One to feel hopeful and empowering, I also want to recognize that life is messy, that right vs wrong isn't so clear, and that not everything can be "fixed."

This is at odds with many ideas of games that have win conditions. Is it possible to make a (satisfying) game without "winning." Perhaps sub-systems will be successfully completed but the larger system, like life, will continue unresolved.

# Magic Circle

During your developmental years, you may play little games with your friends. Tag, hide and go seek, dates, etc. How you play in these games affects the way you develop and form social bonds.

One specific concept I'd like to explore is the idea of the magic circle or imaginary boundaries that exist to delineate special or sacred space. For example, during a game of war with your friends, you may draw lines in the dirt to designate some border. Physically, you may cross the line, but doing so breaks the contact of the game. If you are caught, there may be consequences from your peers; if you aren't, you may develop habits of rule breaking or cheating.

Since it's a game, we can add cool little effects or visualizations.

I'd like to be a concept introduced early on so that it can grow and mature throughout the game.
Games can do all sorts of things like physically preventing you from going into an area, but I'd like it if some of those limitations were enforced by the player themselves instead of the game. Or to make it unclear which rules are really enforced, requiring risk to check.

> People who prefer to work with "**data**." They like to "think and observe rather than act, to organize and understand information rather than to persuade." They also prefer "individual rather than people oriented activities."

> People who like to work with "**ideas and things**". They tend to be "creative, open, inventive, original, perceptive, sensitive, independent and emotional." # Harmonic groups

**Coping style**

How types cope when they don't get what they want. How we defend against loss and disappointment.

# Positive-outlook

*Deny they have any problems.*

**[7]** "There may be a problem, but I'm fine"

Emphasizes positive experiences. Avoids seeing their pain and emptiness. Overemphasis of own needs.

**[9]** "What's the problem? I don't think there's a problem"

Emphasizes positive qualities of others. Avoids seeing problems with their loved ones. Overwhelmed by needs of everyone.

**[2]** "You have a problem and I'm here to help"

Emphasizes positive self-image. Avoids seeing their own neediness and anger. Overemphasis of others' needs.

# Competency

*Cut off feelings and solve problems logically.*

**[1]** "I'm sure we can solve this like mature adults"

Emphasizes being correct and organized. Manages feelings with repression and denial. Work with system, "good boy / girl."

**[3]** "There's an efficient solution, we need to get to work"

# Five Stages of Grief

Copied from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_stages_of_grief

## 1. Denial

> The first reaction is denial. In this stage, individuals believe the diagnosis is somehow mistaken, and cling to a false, preferable reality.

## 2. Anger

> When the individual recognizes that denial cannot continue, they become frustrated, especially at proximate individuals. Certain psychological responses of a person undergoing this phase would be: "Why me? It's not fair!"; "How can this happen to me?"; "Who is to blame?"; "Why would this happen?".

## 3. Bargaining

> The third stage involves the hope that the individual can avoid a cause of grief. Usually, the negotiation for an extended life is made in exchange for a reformed lifestyle. People facing less serious trauma can bargain or seek compromise. Examples include the terminally ill person who "negotiates with God" to attend a daughter's wedding, an attempt to bargain for more time to live in exchange for a reformed lifestyle or a phrase such as "If I could trade their life for mine".

## 4. Depression

> "I'm so sad, why bother with anything?"; "I'm going to die soon, so what's the point?"; "I miss my loved one; why go on?" During the fourth stage, the individual despairs at the recognition of their mortality. In this state, the individual may become silent, refuse visitors and spend much of the time mournful and sullen.

## 5. Acceptance

> "It's going to be okay."; "I can't fight it; I may as well prepare for it." In this last stage, individuals embrace mortality or inevitable future, or that of a loved one, or other tragic event. People dying may precede the survivors in this state, which typically comes with a calm, retrospective view for the individual, and a stable condition of emotions.
